issue.title: Parse old versions of sdf files without warnings

content.raw:
1. I agree we shouldn't promote the use of older code, but if a file is unaffected by a change in sdf version I don't think we should have to touch it. For example, in the change from 1.3 -> 1.4, we renamed three elements in the `<world><physics>` block
(for example `update_rate` to `real_time_update_rate`, see
[here](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/778bf6bc844dbff80ed6131627be1cc1618747c5/sdf/1.4/1_3.convert?at=default)).
This affects world files but not model files.
I think it causes unnecessary work and significant duplication of code to duplicate all the model files just to bump the version number. When there are actual changes, then yes we should update the model file, but only in specific cases (I'm planning to update the polaris models to sdf 1.5 for example to take advantage of the joint axis frame fix).

2. Assuming that SDF versions don't happen that often is an argument against making it easy to change things, which slows down development. I'm not hoping to release a new sdf version every week, but I think it's worth streamlining the process.

3. Curve ball here. Not sure whether anything I said will be relevant for long.
